moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: The critical variation, Black offers a pawn.
moves.10. Kb1: White plays a line introduced by L.Milov
moves.10... Nxd4:
My sources are out of date (1995) but show two other lines where White seems to be doing well.
A) 11...Nd7 12 Bxd4 Nxe5  (12 ...e6 13 f4 f6 14 exf6 Bxf6 15 Qe3 Nb6 16 h4 Milov-Cirkvencic, Nagykanizsa Open 1993) 13 Qe3 Nc6 14 Bxg7 Kxg7 15 Nxd5  Qa5 16 b4 
Qa4 17 b5 Rb8 18 Qxb3 19 axb3 e6 20 bxc6 exd5 L.Milov-Golubev, Biel 1994 and here John Nunn in his 1995 book "Beating the Sicilian 3" recommended 21 Rxd5 axc6 22 Ra5.  I am sure that a lot has happen in the past 15 years and maybe someone can bring us up to date.
moves.16... f5 17. f4: the first new move.  17 Nxd4 f4 has been played here and Black is considered to have good compensation for the exchange.
moves.18... Nxf1 19. Re8+ Bf8 20. Qxd4: 20 Rxf1 Qxb5 21 Rfe1 b6 22 Qxd4 Bb7-+ according to Fritz
moves.20... Qxb5: Fritz considers the position to be equal after 21...Qxd4
moves.21. Qd8 Nd2+ 22. Kc2 Qa4+ 23. Kc1 Qxe8 2: Radjabov has three minor pieces vs. Whites Queen, if Black can get his pieces coordinated he would have an advantage.
moves.29. Rd7 Bxd7 30. Qxa8 Bc6 31. Qxa7 Nc5 3: And White will be able manage a perpetual check.
